question: We were making a commercial down at the mayor's office, and there was this young, good-looking salesman... ...and your mother was throwing herself at him in a disgusting way, and when she found she was too old to seduce him, that he was just embarrassed by her--

question: I have a little headache from this weather.

question: ...which I did not get.
answer: Awwww...

question: So what's new?
answer: Boy--

question: They said I was too offbeat looking, whatever the hell that means.
answer: Oh, what do they know?

question: Oh, God...
answer: Yeah, although it's put an end to the Stanislavski Catering Company. Which is why I have to speak to you. And... you're gonna get impatient, but...I have to borrow some more money.

question: Well, that...th-that's fine.
answer: But what I decided to do is some writing. Yeah, I think I've had it with acting. You know, these meaningless auditions at cattle calls. And I can't handle another rejection. Now let's face it here. I gotta, you know, latch on to something in my life. You know--something with a future. I'm not sixteen anymore. It's just...crazy! I've got...an idea for a story. More than one. And I just need a few months, you know, or, uh, a year even. I've picked up a lot about dramatic structure from doing my scenes in acting class.

question: Well, that-that's good. It just, uh...it just seems to me that-that six months or a year, if-if you spent it more productively...
answer: Well-well, like what?

question: Well, I don't know. We'd uh, uh, um... Didn't Mom mention there was something...something at the Museum of Broadcasting?
answer: Yeah, that's clerical.

question: No. She, didn't she say it was, um...she said it was in the publicity department. That-that can lead to other things.
answer: Boy, I knew you'd be discouraging.

question: I'm not! I'm not! I'm trying to be helpful. A person doesn't just say one day, "Okay, now-now I'm finished as an actress. Now I'm a writer." I mean--
answer: Yeah, you mean not at my age.

question: Yeah, you mean not at my age.
answer: Oh, please! We all came to have lunch, didn't we?

question: Yeah, okay, right. Forget it. What's to eat?
answer: Boy...Holly...Holly.

question: You treat me like a loser.
answer: How?

question: You never have any faith in my plans. You always undercut my enthusiasm.
answer: Not so! No. I think I've been very supportive. I've...I try to give you honest, constructive advice.

question: Hmm!
answer: I'm-I'm always happy to help you financially. I think I've gone out of my way to-to introduce you to interesting single men. There's nothing I would--

question: Uh, losers! All losers!
answer: You're too demanding.

question: You know, I could always tell what you thought of me by the type of men you fixed me up with!
answer: You're crazy! That's not true.

question: What's the matter with you, Lee? Why are you so sensitive all of a sudden?
answer: Look. Listen. Listen. You want to write? Write.

question: What's the matter?
answer: Write! Let's just not talk about it anymore.

question: Good.
answer: Take...take a year. Take six months. Whatever you want. Who knows? Maybe you'll, maybe you'll be sitting with a good play. What's the matter? What's the matter with you? You look pale. You okay?

question: What makes you interested in becoming a Hare Krishna?
answer: Well, I'm not saying that I want to join or anything, but...but I know you guys believe in reincarnation, you know, so it interests me.

question: Yeah, well, what's your religion?
answer: Well, I was born Jewish, you know, but, uh, but last winter I tried to become a Catholic and...it didn't work for me. I-I studied and I tried and I gave it everything, but, you know, Catholicism for me was die now, pay later, you know. And I just couldn't get with it. And I, and I wanted to, you know.

question: You're afraid of dying?
answer: Well...yeah, naturally. Aren't you? I-- L-let me ask you, reincarnation, does that mean my soul would pass to another human being, or would I come back as a moose or an aardvark or something?

question: Take our literature...
answer: Uh-huh.

question: ...read it over, and think about it.
answer: Well, okay. Thank you very much.

question: You're welcome. Hare Krishna.
answer: Who are you kidding? You're gonna be a Krishna? You're gonna shave your head and put on robes and dance around at airports? You'll look like Jerry Lewis. Oh, God, I'm so depressed.

question: Now, here...here's a song that Norma sang on that trip we made up to the show in Buffalo. And, oh, was she beautiful that night!
answer: Come on.

question: Thank you, honey. Oh, yes, you were, dear. Don't you remember that night? She was so beautiful...she was so beautiful that when men saw her walking along the streets, they'd drive their cars right up on the sidewalk. Isn't that right, honey, eh?
answer: A slight exaggeration.

question: I know.
answer: But only slight.

question: Hey, Hannah? You know, I think Lee is really serious about her new boyfriend. Yeah, eh, from what I understand he sounds really nice. I'm so happy for her. I think she's in love. Hey, what's the matter?
answer: I'm real upset about what you wrote.

question: My script?
answer: It's obviously based on Elliot and me.

question: Oh, so loosely.
answer: No, not "Oh, so loosely"! Real specifically! Is that how you see us?

question: Well--
answer: Can I, can I not accept gestures and feelings from people? Do I, do I put people off?

question: Well, it's a made-up story.
answer: No, it's real exact! The-the situations, the dialogue, everything. It's-it's full of intimate details between Elliot and me! Which I don't, I don't see how you could even possibly know about. A conversation we once had about adoption?

question: Well, Lee mentioned that to me, so obviously you discussed it with her. You... I just took the essence and I blew it up into drama.
answer: I don't see how Lee could know about these things. I don't! I don't tell her everything.

question: Wow, I guess I hit a nerve.
answer: You make it sound like, you know, I have no needs or something. You think I'm too self-sufficient?

question: Now, Hannah, that's not what I meant, you know. Uh, yeah, everybody relies on you for so much. "You're so giving. It's not a criticism. We love you. We're grateful."
answer: You're grateful, but you resent me.

question: Oh, wow! I don't want to have this conversation. I didn't do anything wrong. Y-you mentioned to me yourself that you and Elliot were having some problems.
answer: Yeah, we're having some problems, but problems that are my business...which I don't see how you could know about in such detail. How does Lee know about these things? How? They're private!

question: Well, why don't you share them with us?
answer: I don't...I don't want to bother everyone.

question: That's the point. I'd like to be bothered.
answer: I don't see how you could know about these things unless Elliot's been talking to you.

question: It's over, Elliot. I don't know how to make it any clearer. It's over. I can't see you anymore.
answer: Uh... I-I-I know. I deserve this.

question: Look, I'm just as much at fault.
answer: If-if-if you can believe I have such feelings for you!

question: I've got to be honest with you. I met someone else. I've met someone else. I...I told you I wasn't going to wait forever.
answer: But it hasn't been forever.

question: It's been nearly a year since our first time and you're still married to my sister, which...I now realize is fine because you're probably much more in love with her than you know.
answer: Yeah, but we-we made so many plans.

question: Yeah. Uh, well, sure we did. An- an-and in a way you led me on, because I truly believed you were unhappy with Hannah. Otherwise, I would never have let myself be drawn in. I was very weak. So were you. Now I've met someone else. Dinner soon? Uh-huh. Good.
answer: And you're in love overnight?

question: I care a great deal about him, yes.
answer: Lee...

question: Have you been talking to Holly or Lee about us? About our-our personal life?
answer: Me? Of course not.

question: There's things Holly wrote about in her script about us that are so...personal they could only have come from you.
answer: Look, I've got a splitting headache and I don't like being accused.

question: I'm not accusing. I'm asking. Do you...do you find me too...too giving? Too-too-too competent? Too-too, I don't know, disgustingly perfect or something?
answer: No.

question: Well, what is it then? What? Eh, what's come between us? How have I alienated you?
answer: Hannah, my head is throbbing.

question: You never want to talk about it. I-- Every time I bring it up, you- you change the subject. What is it? Do you-- We're communicating less and less. You sleep with me less and less.
answer: Hannah, I am very mixed up! Now please!

question: Do you talk to Holly or Lee behind my back? Do you? You must. They- they seem to know so much about us.
answer: Well, maybe I've asked advice once or twice or-or made a joke.

question: Well, what do you do? Do-do-do you talk to Holly, or Lee, or what? Do you, do you, do you phone them?
answer: Leave me alone, can you?! Jesus, I've told you. I need someone I can matter to.

question: You matter to me. Completely.
answer: It's hard to be around someone who gives so much and-and needs so little in return!

question: But, look...I-I have enormous needs.
answer: Well, I can't see them, and neither can Lee or Holly!

question: It's so pitch-black tonight. I feel lost.
answer: You're not lost. I love you so much.

question: Mmm, I don't know if you remember me, but we had the worst night of my life together.
answer: I remember you.

question: Yes, you do recall, right?
answer: I recall you.

question: I was walking past and I saw you in here...
answer: Yeah.

question: ...and I thought I'd come in and...and we could replay, uh, the whole, uh...
answer: We didn't hit it off.

question: Oh, that's putting it mildly. We did everything but exchange gunshots.
answer: How are you?

question: Good. How are you?
answer: I'm fine.

question: You look wonderful.
answer: Oh, no.

question: Yeah, really. You do. You do.
answer: Yeah?

question: It was a terrible evening.
answer: Yeah, it was.

question: Remember slamming the cab door in my face and.. you know, it came very dangerously close to emasculating my nose in a...
answer: I'd never do that.

question: ...in a really horrible way.
answer: Oh, well, that was a long time ago.

question: You look wonderful. You do. What happened to you?
answer: People change...you know.

question: Well, I hope you've changed.
answer: Yeah, I hope you have, too.

question: I hope so for your sake, because, uh, your personality left something to be desired...
answer: Yeah, and for yours. I'm sure you've changed.

question: ...namely a personality. So how are you?
answer: I'm okay.

question: You didn't answer my question. What are you doing?
answer: Oh, nothing much. You know...

question: Well...
answer: ...just some stuff. A little of this, a little of that, that's all.

question: Yeah? Is that an embarrassing question? Should I have not asked it?
answer: Probably not.

question: Are you, are you out of work or something?
answer: No, well...I've been trying to write.

question: Have you?
answer: Yeah.

question: Well, that's interesting. Wh-what kind of stuff?
answer: Oh...well, you-you're not interested in this.

question: No, you can tell me.
answer: Come on.

question: No, I am. I am.
answer: Oh, no, millions of people come up to you and say, "Hey, I have something I just wrote," right?

question: Nobody ever said it.
answer: Really?

question: This is it. Yeah. This is really--
answer: Well, wo-would you be willing to-to read it? Something...that I wrote?

question: Well, yes, I would if, uh, if it would mean anything to you. I don't know why it would.
answer: No, the reason I ask is--

question: You've always hated my taste in the past.
answer: No, I haven't.

question: You have.
answer: I haven't. No, the reason why I ask is I think it might make a great, uh, television script, and, you know, you're so active in television, so--

question: I'm not anymore. I haven't, I haven't been in television for a year.
answer: You're kidding me.

question: I've done no television whatsoever. No. I may, I may have to get back into it, 'cause my accountant says that I'm running out of dollars. But...but, um, no, I haven't, I just sort of dropped out for a year...
answer: Oh. Oh.

question: ...which is a long, dull story and I won't get into it. But--
answer: You're okay, though, huh?

question: I'm-- Yes. Yes, I'm fine. I'm fine. How are you?
answer: Oh, I'm fine.

question: What...what about your script? So what's it about?
answer: Well, I'd love it if you'd read it, actually, 'cause I really would value your opinion.

question: You have to remember, we-we-we didn't agree on one thing.
answer: But you have to remember while you're reading and you're cursing my name, you know, that this is my first script. Well, it's not my first script.

question: Hmm.
answer: Actually, my first script was about Hannah and her husband, but, uh...

question: Yeah.
answer: ...Hannah read it, she got really angry, and... you know, then I felt badly, so I--

question: Oh, well, God, I can imagine what you wrote.
answer: Oh, no! It wasn't anything bad. But she just... you know. I don't know.

question: Really?
answer: So, uh...I threw it out, but I have this other one.

question: Well, you know, I-I-I...you know, if you want me to, I'll read it.
answer: Oh, gosh, I don't know. Well, could I come over tomorrow and read it to you?

question: Come over tomorrow and read it to me? You must be joking. I've been doing all my own reading since I was forty...you know.
answer: Hmm. I think it's lucky I ran into you. Maybe.

question: Well, what about me?
answer: Oh, well.

question: I should have kept going. I-I have a sneaking feeling, a nagging sensation I should've kept walking and... ...and not begun this conversation.
answer: "We all go through life playing the hand we're dealt. Craig That's the end. No, you can tell me straight. It's okay. Just, you know, tell me what you think.

question: It's great. I swea-- I'm-- I'm, tch, I'm speechless. I was...I was not in the mood to listen to this thing now. I don't know what to say. I'm moved and I laughed and I-- Uh, I, you know, I was on the edge of my seat. I just think it's wonderful! I'm, I'm totally...stunned. This is not an insult. I'm amazed that you can... It was-- I just thought it was great.
answer: Really?

question: Yes! I was abso-- And...w- what...made you think of that climax scene where the, where the... architect is walking home with his actress girlfriend and-and the ex- wife who's schizophrenic jumps out of the bushes and stabs him to death?
answer: Oh, it just came to me one day.

question: Well, it was just fabulous! I'm, I, you know...
answer: Oh, gosh, you really think I can write?

question: I thought it was wonder-- There's maybe one or two things in there that I would do differently myself, but...
answer: Right.

question: ...but who cares? It was just-- It was fabulous.
answer: Oh!

question: Fabulous, I mean it! I'm so impressed.
answer: Oh, God!

question: I am. You-you made my day.
answer: Oh, wow!

question: It was just great. Uh, I was all set...I was set to be bored stiff.
answer: Uh, gee. Would you like to have lunch? Uh, uh...

question: I-I would love to talk to you about, uh, that script. I-I, you know, I think maybe that we could do something with it.
answer: Okay, and listen, I would like to hear what made you suddenly decide to drop out of life.

question: Oh, who cares?
answer: Y-you used to-- Oh, no! Yeah, I care. You used to be so ambitious and... God, you really liked it?! Gosh, you really went through a crisis, you know that? H-how did you get over it? I mean, when I ran into you, you seemed, you seemed just perfectly fine. Well, you seem fine now.

question: Well... I'll tell you. One day about a month ago... ...I really hit bottom. You know, I just felt that in a Godless universe, I didn't want to go on living. Now I happen to own this rifle... ...which I loaded, believe it or not, and pressed it to my forehead. And I remember thinking, at the time, I'm gonna kill myself. Then I thought...what if I'm wrong? What if there is a God? I mean, after all, nobody really knows that. But then I thought, no. You know, maybe is not good enough. I want certainty or nothing. And I remember very clearly the clock was ticking, and I was sitting there frozen, with the gun to my head, debating whether to shoot. All of a sudden, the gun went off. I had been so tense, my finger had squeezed the trigger inadvertently... ...but I was perspiring so much, the gun had slid off my forehead and missed me. And suddenly, neighbors were, were, pounding on the door, and-and I don't know, the whole scene was just pandemonium. And, uh, you know, and I-I-I-I-I ran to the door. I-I-I-I didn't know what to say. You know, I was, I was embarrassed and confused, and my-my-my mind was r-r-racing a mile a minute... ...and I-I jus knew one thing. I...I-I-I-I had to get out of that house. I had to just get out in the fresh air and-and clear my head. And I remember very clearly. I walked the streets. I walked and I walked. I-I didn't know what was going through my mind. It all seemed so violent and un-unreal to me. And I wandered... ...for a long time on the Upper West Side, you know, an-and it must have been hours! You know, my, my feet hurt. My head was, was pounding, and, and I had to sit down. I went into a movie house. I-I didn't know what was playing or anything. I just, I just needed a moment to gather my thoughts and, and be logical, and, and put the world back into rational perspective. And I went upstairs to the balcony, and I sat down and, you know, the movie was a-a-a film that I'd seen many times in my life since I was a kid, an-and I always u-uh, loved it. And, you know, I'm, I'm watching these people up on the screen, and I started getting hooked o-on the film, you know? ...And I started to feel how can you even think of killing yourself? I mean, isn't it so stupid? I mean, l-look at all the people up there on the screen. You know, they're real funny, and, and what if the worst is true? What if there's no God, and you only go around once and that's it? Well, you know, don't you want to be part of the experience? You know, what the hell, it-i-it's not all a drag. And I'm thinking to myself, geez, I should stop ruining my life... ...searching for answers I'm never gonna get, and just enjoy it while it lasts. And...you know... ...after, who knows? I mean, you know, maybe there is something. Nobody really knows. I know, I know "maybe" is a very slim reed to hang your whole life on, but that's the best we have. And...then, I started to sit back, and I actually began to enjoy myself.
answer: Um...look, there's something I've, uh, that's been bothering me for a long time, and I just thought I'd just tell you what it was and just sort of clear the deck here, and that's this.

question: Oh, yeah? What?
answer: That I've always regretted the way I behaved that evening we went out, and, uh...I've, I just thought I'd tell you that because I really made a fool out of myself.

question: Oh, don't be silly! No! Don't be ridiculous.
answer: It's all right.

question: I was the, I was... You know, it was my fault. I-- So, so you want to go out to dinner again? I mean, is that, is that... Have, you have any interest in that, or...
answer: Sure. Sure, uh, yes.

question: Do you? I mean, are you, are you, are you, are you free this evening?
answer: Yeah.
